text: [Music]
the man known as Mara a prominent
Syrian rebel commander surveys
battlefield near Aleppo incoming
ordnance explodes nearby the commanders
followers believe it was intended for
their leader it was a regular frontline
presence and one of Syria's wanted men
as Mara has become well-known and
more successful he has attracted a
government bounty on his head
[Music]
this is CJ chippers reporting for The
New York Times the uprising to unseat
President Bashar al-assad is almost two
years old while Western governments have
raised doubts that its publicly known
leaders many of whom live in Turkey can
unify the rebellion field commanders
like mr. Saleh have emerged on the
ground they fill a leadership void with
inside connections and credibility
earned in battle these men have taken
the reins of the war Haj Amara's birth
name is Abdul Kadir al Saleh he is young
and charismatic
and seen as pragmatic and accommodating
to a Sunni Arab who welcomes other
ethnicities and faiths he's been wounded
several times in the fall he survived an
assassination attempt he still fights
beside his men leaders like him present
foreign governments with the challenge
should they help and work with them
against mr. Assad and develop
connections for after the war
or should they leave them alone as the
United States has and risk alienating
them further as many fighting groups
become more powerful and some of them
become more extreme in January
the New York Times met mr. Saleh and one
of his hidden fighting groups before the
war mr. Saleh had little military
experience he spent two and a half years
as an army conscript and was a traveling
Islamic missionary before returning home
to open a seed shop in Marah
the agricultural town where he was born
when the Revolution began he was a
protester before taking up arms mr.
Saleh now head to the military wing of
al tawheed a force said to field more
than 6,000 men he commands the battle
for Aleppo Syria's largest city and it's
gained a devoted following the town of
Marah has become a target of Syria's
military his supporters say the
government punishes those associated
with him a large crater apparently from
a ballistic missile attack sits in a
wheat field beside Marah the result of
an explosion in the night his townsman
have stood by him
the government forces have not been
dislodged and much of Aleppo has been
damaged the city's residents facing
daily dangers and shortages grew
frustrated long ago you could see the
sharp shooting weather so good so good I
love the fanatical arrow so good after
we go fighting without foreign military
support and with few weapons mr. Saleh
said America's inaction has made serious
conditions worse endangering the West's
long-term interests and relationships in
the Middle East
serious fighters say the tide narrows
for answers to the questions in the West
in Mara and north of Aleppo Mr Sallis
fighters have already dug their own
graves man
